choices.text: AML and Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers

questions.text: A 5-year-old child being evaluated for pancytopenia was found to have an abnormality as shown in the picture. He also has short stature and multiple café-au-lait macules on his body. Chromosomal breakage studies are indicative of increased fragility of chromatids. HSCT is planned, but the parents are counselled about the potential for increased morbidity and mortality due to the elevated risk of some specific complications. What is the likely set of complications most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Explanation::

  • The clinical findings of pancytopenia, thumb/radial anomalies, short stature, café-au-lait spots, and chromosomal breakage strongly suggest Fanconi Anaemia, a congenital bone marrow failure syndrome.
  • Children with Fanconi anaemia are at significantly increased risk of developing:
    • Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML)
    • Squamous cell carcinomas of the head, neck, and anogenital region, especially following hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT).
    • This risk is compounded by the patient's underlying DNA repair defect and exposure to conditioning regimens during HSCT.

Explanation for other options:

Cirrhosis and CLL (Option A): These are not commonly associated complications of Fanconi anaemia. CLL is rare in children.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C): Rhabdomyosarcoma is a childhood cancer, but not a known common malignancy in Fanconi anaemia.

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma of the gut (Option D): Not classically associated with Fanconi anaemia. Lymphoid malignancies are rare in these patients.

questions.text: Brentuximab vedotin is useful in the management of which malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Brentuximab vedotin is an anti-CD30 antibody-drug conjugate used in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma, particularly in:
    • Refractory/relapsed cases,
    • High-risk patients,
    • And is being evaluated as part of first-line therapy when combined with standard chemotherapy.
  • It works by combining a monoclonal antibody targeting CD30 with monomethyl auristatin E, a cytotoxic agent, thereby delivering targeted chemotherapy to Hodgkin Reed-Sternberg cells.

Explanation of other options:

Burkitt lymphoma (Option A): Burkitt lymphoma is a CD20+ B-cell lymphoma and does not express CD30. Brentuximab is not useful.

AML (Option C): AML treatment does not involve anti-CD30 therapy. Brentuximab has no role.

JMML (Option D): Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukaemia is a myeloproliferative neoplasm in children; it is not CD30 positive.

choices.text: Parallel rays of tubular structure in lysosomes

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was found to have hepatosplenomegaly and delayed milestones. The liver biopsy and bone marrow biopsy revealed PAS-positive histiocytes. Electron microscope findings of these histiocytes will most likely be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly along with PAS-positive histiocytes is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH).
  • LCH is characterised by a clonal proliferation of monocyte-derived Langerhans cells.
  • Birbeck granules, visible under electron microscopy, are classic for LCH and appear as "tennis racket"-shaped bilaminar structures in the cytoplasm.
  • Although not always necessary, electron microscopy helps confirm the diagnosis. Additional immunohistochemical markers include S-100 and CD1a positivity.

Explanation of other options:

Myelin figures (Option B): Seen in metabolic or lysosomal storage disorders like Niemann-Pick disease; not in LCH.

Parallel tubular structures (Option C): These are characteristic of certain peroxisomal or lysosomal storage disorders.

Electron-dense mitochondrial deposits (Option D): Typically seen in mitochondrial disorders, not in histiocytosis.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old son with Down syndrome to the clinic because his gums have been bleeding for 2 weeks. She reports that he has been less energetic than usual and also has bone pain. Examination reveals that the child has an oral temperature of 100°F, pallor, splenomegaly, gingival bleeding, and bruises on the lower extremities. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this clinical context is acute leukaemia, based on the presence of:

  • Constitutional symptoms: fever, fatigue, bone pain
  • Bleeding: gingival bleeding, bruises
  • Haematological signs: pallor (anaemia), thrombocytopenia, possible leukopenia or leukocytosis
  • Organomegaly, especially splenomegaly, which is uncommon in isolated ITP
  • Risk factor: Children with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing acute leukaemia, particularly acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) after the age of 1 year.

Explanation of other options:

Aplastic anaemia (Option A): Typically presents with pancytopenia but without organomegaly or bone pain.

ITP (Option B): Presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding; organomegaly and bone pain are not features.

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option D): Can cause pallor and mild hepatosplenomegaly, but not bleeding or bone pain; very rare at this age in well-nourished children.

questions.text: What type of chromosomal abnormality is associated with acute promyelocytic leukaemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chromosomal translocation (15;17) is the hallmark of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukaemia (AML).
  • This translocation results in the fusion of the PML gene on chromosome 15 with the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARα) gene on chromosome 17, forming the PML-RARA fusion gene.
  • This fusion gene disrupts normal myeloid differentiation, leading to the accumulation of promyelocytes.
  • All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) therapy targets this molecular defect and is a specific treatment for APL, promoting differentiation of the leukemic cells.

Explanation of other options:

t(12;21) (Option A): Associated with childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL), especially with a favourable prognosis.

t(4;11) (Option C): Seen in infant ALL, associated with MLL gene rearrangement, poor prognosis.

t(9;22) (Option D): The Philadelphia chromosome, more typical in chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) and some cases of adult ALL.

questions.text: A 2-year-old has been diagnosed with ALL. Which among the following will be the one having a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among pediatric patients with ALL, several factors determine prognosis. The most favourable prognostic factors include:

  • Age between 1 and 10 years (best: 2-8 years)
  • WBC count <50,000/mm³ at presentation (Option C ruled out)
  • Pre-B cell ALL phenotype
  • Hyperdiploidy (chromosome count >50)
  • Absence of unfavorable genetic translocations, e.g., t(9;22) and t(4;11) (Option B ruled out)
  • Rapid early response to therapy

Explanation of other options:

Mediastinal involvement (Option D): Seen in T-cell ALL, usually associated with higher risk features

questions.text: The following columns A and B contain types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma and the corresponding key characteristics in a random manner. Kindly identify the correct match of the respective columns?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nodular Sclerosis → R. Lacunar cells
    • The most common subtype in developed countries
    • Pathognomonic lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells in fibrotic bands
    • Seen more in adolescents and young adults
  • Mixed Cellularity → Q. Most common in India
    • Frequently seen in developing countries
    • Associated with EBV infection
    • No sclerosis or lacunar cells
  • Nodular Lymphocyte Predominance → S. Excellent prognosis
    • Also called the "Popcorn cell" variant
    • Lacks classical Reed-Sternberg cells
    • Best overall prognosis
  • Lymphocyte Depletion → P. Reticular Variant
    • Least common
    • Seen in older age or advanced disease
    • Poor prognosis

Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

questions.text: A child presented with proptosis. You suspect it to be a chloroma. Next investigation to make the diagnosis, among the following is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patients withAM present with signs and symptoms that are uncommon, like subcutaneous nodules or "blueberry muffin" lesions (especially in infants), infiltration of the gingiva (especially in monocytic subtypes), signs and laboratory findings of disseminated intravascular coagulation (especially indicative of APL), and discrete masses, known as chloromas or granulocytic sarcomas.
  • Chloromas (also called granulocytic sarcomas) are extramedullary solid tumours composed of immature myeloid cells, most often seen in association with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML).
  • They can present with proptosis, orbital masses, bone involvement, or skin nodules.
  • They are commonly associated with t(8;21)
  • Peripheral blood smear is the initial investigation of choice as it may reveal myeloblasts, suggesting AML.
  • Confirmation involves bone marrow aspiration and flow cytometry.
  • Platelet count (Option A), WBC count (Option C), and Haemoglobin (Option D) may provide supportive data but are nonspecific and not diagnostic for chloroma or leukaemia.

questions.text: A child with an underlying malignancy developed tumour lysis syndrome. Which among the following is the most likely such malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS) is a life-threatening oncologic emergency caused by rapid destruction of malignant cells.
  • It is characterised by metabolic abnormalities including:
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Hypocalcemia
  • Burkitt's lymphoma is one of the most rapidly proliferating tumours, hence most frequently associated with TLS.
  • TLS commonly occurs within 12-72 hours of starting chemotherapy, although spontaneous TLS has also been reported.
  • Complications include acute renal failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures, requiring aggressive supportive care.

Explanation of other options:

Hodgkin's lymphoma (Option A): Hodgkin lymphoma is generally slow-growing compared to aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphomas like Burkitt's.While it is highly responsive to therapy, tumour lysis syndrome is rare in Hodgkin lymphoma due to its lower tumour burden and slower cell turnover rate.

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) (Option C): CLL is primarily a disease of older adults and is extremely rare in children. Although TLS can occur in adult patients with CLL who receive intensive chemotherapy, it is not a relevant pediatric differential.

Wilms' tumour (Option D): Wilms' tumour is a pediatric renal malignancy and may present with a large tumour burden. However, it is a solid tumour, and although TLS can rarely occur in bulky solid tumours, this is uncommon.

questions.text: A boy presented with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. With the image provided, identify the abnormal cell, the viral pathogen associated and the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, which is the pathognomonic hallmark of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).
  • RS cells are large cells (15-45 μm) with bilobed or multilobed nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm.
  • They often have an "owl's eye" appearance, as seen in the image.
  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with approximately 40-50% of pediatric HL cases, especially the mixed cellularity subtype.
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presentation of HL in children.

Thus, the correct triad is:

  • Cell: Reed-Sternberg cell
  • Virus: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)
  • Diagnosis: Hodgkin's lymphoma

Explanation of other options:

RS cells, CMV, Hodgkin's Lymphoma (Option B): CMV is not associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma. RS cells are present, but EBV, not CMV, is the associated viral pathogen.

RS cells, CMV, Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (Option C): Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does not show Reed-Sternberg cells on histology. Additionally, CMV has no known causative association with NHL.

RS cells, EBV, Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (Option D): RS cells are specific for HL and not seen in NHL. While EBV is associated with HL, this option is incorrect due to the lymphoma type mismatch.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Wilms' tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wilms' tumour is a pediatric renal tumour that is associated with several congenital syndromes.

  • Aniridia is seen in WAGR syndrome (Wilms tumour, Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, mental Retardation). (Option A)
  • Macroglossia is a feature of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which includes Wilms tumour, omphalocele, and hemihypertrophy. (Option B)
  • Gonadoblastoma can occur in Denys-Drash syndrome, which also includes Wilms' tumour, nephropathy, and ambiguous genitalia. (Option C)
  • However, Retinoblastoma is not associated with Wilms' tumour and is instead linked to RB1 gene mutations and other distinct syndromes.
  • Syndromes like Bloom Syndrome, Frasier Syndrome and Li-Fraumeni Syndrome also carry an increased risk of Wilms Tumour.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of a progressively enlarging, firm abdominal mass. He also has periorbital ecchymosis and complains of bone pain. A bone scan is advised by the pediatric oncologist to evaluate the extent of the disease. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour of childhood and frequently presents with:
    • Abdominal mass, often arising from the adrenal gland or sympathetic chain
    • Bone pain due to skeletal metastasis
    • Periorbital ecchymosis ("raccoon eyes") from orbital bone metastases
    • Bone scan is typically used to evaluate the extent of bony metastases
  • Skeletal metastases, particularly to orbital bones, are characteristic of neuroblastoma and are seen in over 50% of patients at presentation.

Explanation of other options:

Retinoblastoma (Option B): Primarily presents with leukocoria or strabismus; bone metastases are rare.

NHL (Option C): May present with abdominal masses, but bone metastases are uncommon.

PNET (Option D): These tumours can be aggressive and metastasise, but bony spread is not typical at presentation in young children.

questions.text: Trilateral retinoblastoma comprises bilateral retinoblastomas along with which of the following tumours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trilateral retinoblastoma refers to a condition where a child with bilateral retinoblastoma (RB) develops an associated intracranial midline tumour, most commonly pinealoblastoma.
  • This rare but recognised syndrome is due to the same underlying germline RB1 mutation that predisposes to bilateral RB.
    • Seen in ~5% of children with bilateral RB.
    • These tumours typically present within the first 5 years of life.
    • MRI brain screening is recommended in bilateral RB to detect this early.

Explanation of other options:

Osteogenic sarcoma (Option A): The most common secondary malignancy in children with heritable RB, but not a component of trilateral RB.

Medulloblastoma (Option B): Common pediatric CNS tumour, but not related to RB or its trilateral form.

Teratoma (Option D): Germ cell tumour, not associated with bilateral RB or trilateral RB.

choices.text: Undifferentiated tumours have a bad outcome, while well-differentiated tumours have a better outcome
Optic nerve involvement is considered to be a bad prognostic sign
Despite good radiosensitivity, the mainstay of management is chemotherapy and surgery
Enucleation is needed in the anterior chamber involvement

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding retinoblastoma is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The degree of tumour differentiation in retinoblastoma does not correlate with prognosis. Therefore, whether a tumour is well- or poorly differentiated does not predict clinical outcome.
  • Involvement of the optic nerve is indeed a poor prognostic indicator as it suggests advanced local spread. (Option B)
  • Although retinoblastoma is radiosensitive, the preferred treatment today is systemic chemotherapy combined with focal therapies (laser/cryotherapy), especially to preserve vision. (Option C)
  • Enucleation is considered in cases with extensive anterior chamber involvement, poor visual potential, or globe-threatening disease. (Option D)

choices.text: Risk is similar in all syndromic forms

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes carries the highest risk of developing Wilms' tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the syndromes associated with Wilms' tumour, Denys-Drash syndrome has the highest risk of tumour development.
  • Nearly 90% of affected individuals develop Wilms' tumour due to mutations involving the WT1 gene.

questions.text: The most common intra-abdominal tumour in a 3-year-old child is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common intra-abdominal tumour in infancy is neuroblastoma, but in the 2-5-year age group, Wilms tumour becomes the most common.
  • The peak incidence of Wilms' tumour is between 2-3 years, whereas neuroblastoma is typically seen in infants.
  • Wilms' tumour arises from nephrogenic rests and often presents as a painless abdominal mass in toddlers.

Explanation of other options:

Neuroblastoma (Option A): More common in infancy; rare beyond age 2-3. It may arise from the adrenal or sympathetic chain.

Medullary cystic kidney (Option C): A hereditary tubulointerstitial kidney disease, not a tumour; does not present as an abdominal mass.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option D): A soft tissue sarcoma that may arise in various locations, but is less commonly intra-abdominal.

questions.text: Which of the following events is associated with a "good" outcome in neuroblastoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trk A expression is a well-established favourable prognostic factor in neuroblastoma.
  • Trk A is a receptor for nerve growth factor, and its expression is associated with tumours that are biologically more mature, differentiated, and responsive to treatment.
  • Children with Trk A-positive tumours generally have a better prognosis compared to those lacking Trk A expression.
  • Other favourable prognostic features include:
    • Age <18 months at diagnosis
    • Low-stage disease (INRG Stage L1, L2, MS)
    • Non-amplified N-myc
    • Hyperdiploidy
    • Absence of segmental chromosomal abnormalities
    • Favorable histology
  • Conversely, N-myc amplification and chromosome 1p deletion are associated with poor prognosis. Diploidy is not a favourable factor either.

Explanation of other options:
N-myc amplification (Option A): Associated with aggressive disease and poor prognosis. Its amplification indicates rapid tumour progression and poor response to therapy.

Chromosome 1p deletion (Option B): Correlates with adverse outcome and is considered a poor prognostic factor in neuroblastoma.

Diploidy (Option C): Diploid tumours behave more aggressively and are associated with unfavourable outcomes. Hyperdiploidy is instead associated with a better prognosis.

choices.text: Most are located in the midline and/or below the tentorium cerebri.
Brain tumours are a rare type of cancer in childhood.
Signs of increased intracranial pressure are rare in midline tumours.
Seizures are the presenting complaint in all cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about childhood brain tumours is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most childhood brain tumours are infratentorial in location and frequently arise in the midline structures such as the cerebellum and brainstem.
  • This distinguishes them from adult brain tumours, which are more often supratentorial.
  • Brain tumours are relatively common in children, representing the most common solid tumour and the second most common malignancy overall after leukaemia. (Option B)
  • Signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) are commonly seen in midline brain tumours, especially medulloblastomas. (Option C)
  • Seizures are more typical of supratentorial tumours and are not a consistent presenting feature in all pediatric brain tumours. (Option D)

questions.text: Dinutuximab has been recently approved for which of the following pediatric malignancies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dinutuximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets GD2, a disialoganglioside highly expressed on neuroblastoma cells.
  • It is approved for use in high-risk neuroblastoma patients following autologous stem cell transplant:
    • Improves 2-year event-free survival from ~46.5% to ~66.5%
    • Used during the consolidation phase of therapy
    • Administered as part of a multimodal approach in high-risk disease
    • Approved by the US FDA as the standard of care for post-transplant consolidation in high-risk cases

The treatment of neuroblastoma depends on the stage and risk group:

  • Low-risk: Often managed by observation or surgery alone.
  • Intermediate- and high-risk: Require multimodal therapy, including induction chemotherapy, surgical resection, and consolidation therapy (± radiotherapy).
  • Therefore, the mainstay of treatment per Nelson remains chemotherapy and surgery.

Explanation of other options:

ALL (Option A): Treated with chemotherapy ± stem cell transplant, no role of Dinutuximab.

Wilms' tumour (Option C): Treated with nephrectomy and chemotherapy/radiation.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option D): Treated with chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiation; no role of Dinutuximab.

questions.text: Chang Staging is used in pediatric malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chang staging is a classification system specific to medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric brain tumour, particularly in the 5-7 year age group.
  • Tumour is typically midline, infratentorial, and arises from the cerebellar vermis
  • Frequently causes obstructive hydrocephalus, leading to raised ICP
  • Spreads via cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), thus spreading metastases to the spinal cord
  • Chang staging includes:
    • T stage (based on tumour size and extension)
    • M stage (based on CSF and extraneural spread)

Explanation of other options:

ALL (Option A): Staged using immunophenotyping and risk stratification, not Chang staging

Retinoblastoma (Option C): Uses International Classification (not Chang)

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option D): Uses TNM or Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study (IRS) system.

questions.text: What is the most common extracranial solid malignancy in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid malignancy of childhood, typically arising from the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia.

It accounts for:

  • Approximately 7-10% of all childhood cancers
  • 15% of childhood cancer-related deaths
  • Commonly diagnosed below 5 years of age
  • Most often presents as an abdominal mass, frequently crossing the midline.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in with an abdominal mass. Imaging suggests a renal origin. There is a history of metastasis to the lungs, liver, and lymph nodes. FNAC and blind biopsy are avoided due to the risk of upstaging. The child responds well to chemotherapy with vincristine, actinomycin D, and doxorubicin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wilms' tumour is the most common renal tumour of childhood and typically presents between 2-5 years of age.

  • Clue 1-Pediatric malignancy in young children. Wilms' tumour occurs in children aged 2-3 years.
  • Clue 2-Metastases to the lung, lymph nodes and liver are seen in Wilms' tumour
  • Clue 3- Blind biopsy is avoidedsince itcan upstage the disease. Imaging studies include plain abdominal radiography, abdominal ultrasonography (US), and CT of the abdomen to define the intrarenal origin of the mass and differentiate it from adrenal masses (e.g., neuroblastoma) and other masses in the abdomen.
  • Clue 4- Responds to chemotherapy with Vincristine, Actinomycin-D and Doxorubicin- Seen in Wilms Tumour. After radical nephrectomy, most patients receive chemotherapy using the said agents.
  • Imaging modalities such as USG, CT scan, or X-ray help distinguish Wilms tumour from other abdominal masses like neuroblastoma.
  • Biopsy is avoided before surgery unless the diagnosis is unclear, and image-guided core needle biopsy is used with caution.

Explanation of other options:

Neuroblastoma (Option A): May cross midline, often presents with systemic features like opsoclonus-myoclonus; does not typically respond to the mentioned chemo regimen.

Lymphoblastic leukaemia (Option B): Primarily a hematologic malignancy, it does not present with a renal mass.

Hodgkin's lymphoma (Option D): Rare in this age group and not typically associated with abdominal renal masses.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a painful mass involving her right fourth rib. Biopsy reveals small, round blue cells. Identification of which of the following translocations by FISH would confirm the diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most characteristic cytogenetic abnormality associated with Ewing sarcoma is the translocation t(11;22)(q24;q12).
  • This translocation results in the formation of the EWS-FLI1 fusion gene, a crucial diagnostic marker.
  • Molecular identification of this fusion transcript using RT-PCR or FISH helps confirm the diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma and differentiates it from other small round blue cell tumours.

Genetic Translocations and Associated Pediatric Malignancies

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presents with a history of haematuria for 2 days. On examination, there is a palpable abdominal mass. Investigations to be performed are mentioned below.
1. CT
bdomen
2. PET
3. FNAC
4. Biopsy
What investigations should be done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A ballotable abdominal mass with haematuria in a3-year-old child is highly likely to be of renal origin, likely a Wilms tumour.

  • CT abdomen helps to differentiate cystic and solid masses and also helps in the staging of the disease.
  • PET is indicated for suspected malignancy to determine the location of metastasis.
  • FNAC and biopsyare generally avoided in a suspected Wilms tumour during initial work-up to avoid seeding and upstaging.
